Neel Garde Datasheet as part of Water Quality Monitor for Team 210

Submission: October, 27, 2025

Introduction

Neel Garde's individual EGR304 subsystem datasheet Project Summary

This is the datasheet for Neel Garde's subsystem of Team 210's water quality monitoring device - see team report.

My Contribution

  • My contribution to the team project is the controller/user interface subsystem.
  • This subsystem serves as a motherboard to connect and control the other three sensor subsystems to make a functional water quality monitoring device
  • To review the system's schematic, you can review it in the "schematic" section of the datasheet
  • To review ta block diagram of the system, you can review it in the "block diagram" section of the datasheet
  • To review the details listed of the material used to construct the subsection, you can review it in the "BOM" section of the datasheet.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The main contribution to this project by myself is the motherboard unit, which will connect, synchronize and provide input/output to the user via buttons, lights, a screen, and a speaker.

  • power levels:
  • PIC, speaker and communications between boards will be running at 5V.
  • LCD and controller will be running at 3.3V. 3.3V regulator can be operated off 5V or 9V rails.
  • 9V will be used to power the 5V and 3.3V rail regulators.
  • sensors: 4 buttons will be used for user inputs
  • Actuator: A speaker will be used for warnings
  • team connections: 3 other teammates will connect via digital signaling to give sensor data in numerial format via UART
  • Power source: 9V battery, barrel jack charger or sharing 5V rail with teammates through 8-pin headers.

docs.title: Component Selection
docs.text:
3.3V voltage regulator

Image Product Price Pros Cons LM1117T-3.3/NOPB $1.61 high current overhead (800mA) Integrated heatsink bulky LP2950-33LPE3 $1.37 compact Pins are closer together for peralta milling, may require spreading LE33CZ-AP $1.01 Compact Pins are well spread cheap none

Decision: The LE33CZ-AP will be chosen for it’s size, cost, and ease of assembly with the peralta mill specs. Since the LCD subsystem and level shifters won’t draw more than 10mA, the 100mA rating is more than sufficient.

Speaker

Image Product Price Pros Cons SP-1511S-3 $2.37 Compact Moderate volume Inexpensive Requires tight soldering Up-firing, complicates enclosure design No waterproofing rating CSS-40408N $12.31 Very loud Possibly waterproof (not rated Easy soldering Expensive Not very compact on board SPKM.10.8.A $2.31 Low price Very loud Low power draw compact Not waterproof

Decision: The SPKM.10.8.A will be chosen due to it’s low size, high volume, and inexpensiveness being ideal for the application of an alarm system.

LCD Screen

Image Product Price Pros Cons NHD-0216K1Z-NSW-BBW-L $7.92 Programming is clearly described 4-bit more to save lane count 2 lines of characters Built in controller May not show well in bright light or an angle NHD-C0220BIZ-FSW-FBW-3V3M $11.41 Easy to read in bright light 2 lines of characters Built in controller More complicated but well documented programming No 8-bit mode for higher control NHD-0420AZ-FSW-GBW-33V3 $13.64 4 lines of characters Easy readability in bright light Built in controller Optional 4 bit mode Requires more space on enclosure

Decision: The NHD-0420AZ-FSW-GBW-33V3 will be chosen to allow for more complex data or text to be displayed. The cost is slightly higher than other models, but the increased readability, size, and well documented programming offsets this.

Switch button

Image Product Price Pros Cons 3-1825910-5 $0.16 Inexpensive Moderate height for clearing enclosure Thin surface, no lettering options 84SN-CC3-000 $22.87 Convenient packaging Allows for more complex input Large button surface Expensive Large B3F-4050 $0.26 Inexpensive Allows for a keycap to be mounted Requires a keycap to be designed with proper tolerances

Decision: The B3F-4050 will be chosen to allow for efficient enclosure design, cost, and ease of use by providing a labeled and large button surface via custom keycap.

Switch Debouncing

Solution Pros Cons Custom debouncing circuit Guaranteed functionality regardless of PIC state Simple to design Requires board space Adds complexity to BOM and circuitry Software debouncing Saves board space Reduces hardware complexity Requires a timer circuit. Since there is no OS on the PIC, only one hardware timer is available. Since scheduling method is unknown, all program must be run as a single thread, or the debouncing may not be accurate May not function at startup of PIC

Decision: A custom debouncing circuit will be chosen due to the complexity of porting an OS (such as FreeRTOS) to the PIC to share timer resources and the option to have the user use buttons on the PIC’s startup to enter debugging modes.

Level Shifters

Image Product Price Pros Cons V62/24621-01XE $3.48 Provides 6 circuits,simplifying board Simple pin layout Fast switching Will not arrive in time, out of stock SMD CD40109BPWR $0.46 Does not require high voltage supply Only has 4 circuits, so 2 units will be required SMD 74AXP2T45DCH $0.77 Compact THT Unidirectional Only has 4 circuits, so 2 units will be required

Decision: The 74AXP2T45DCH will be selected due to it’s ease of soldering and compactness. While bidirectional capability would help with future modification, it is not worth the tradeoffs for this project.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This schematic is design to support a water-quality monitoring system. This subsystem functions as a user interface, supporting up to 4 sensor boards to be added to it. It features a speaker to alert the user of dangerous levels, as well as a screen and button interface.

Figure 1: Controller subsystem schematic.

docs.title: Design Process
docs.text: Element Design Process MCU pin assignments Allocated by datasheet 8-pin header pin assignments Project specification Switch pull-up resistors From my research, the pull-up size can be within an  acceptable range and min and max size can be calculated with the current and capacitance of the MCU pins. If the MCU is not especially sensitive, 10k is a generally accepted standard for 5V microcontrollers. Debouncing low-pass filter (RC) Using the relationship debouncetime \= 5RC, and an arbitrary debounce of 10 ms (assumed to be a reasonable time for a human to make a confident input without becoming annoying), and a capacitor value of 0.1 uF to keep physical size down, I calculated a 20kOhm resistor would be suitable. LCD header pin assignments Pins allocated by datasheet. A level shifter is used to translate the 5V logic from the PIC to the 3.3V logic required by the LCD controller daughterboard. Speaker design Design from in-class lab updated with datasheet for specific speaker used. A voltage divider was added to better suit the speaker's frequency-voltage chart. Power supplies Basic design from datasheets. A second 5V input with a diode and fuse was added to the 3.3V regulator to allow functioning when being powered by another subsystem. The diodes and fuse are to prevent the 9V supply from being connected to the 5V rail.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: As this subsystem involves multiple active components and an actuator, a power budget was required to ensure that the two main rails and regulators would be sufficient, and that our plan of sharing a 5V rail from the pH sensor subsystem would be feasible.

docs.title: Conclusions
docs.text: The power draw of the controller subsystem is minimal when the speaker is off, and both wall-power and power-sharing with teammates should be no issue. When the speaker is on, it is still well within safety. It can be assumed the the power draw from teammate subsystems will be minimal since there are no actuators involved.
